metadata.description: Velocity analysis scenarios with realistic team data

scenarios.title: Stable Team - E-commerce Platform
scenarios.description: A mature team working on an e-commerce platform with consistent membership
scenarios.context: This team has been working together for 8 months on a well-established product. They have stable requirements and good technical practices.

questions.question: What is the team's average velocity over the last 6 sprints?
What velocity range should this team use for sprint planning?
questions.explanation: Based on recent performance, 28-33 points captures the typical range while accounting for complexity variation

questions.question: How many sprints would it take to complete a 95-point epic?
questions.explanation: At 31 points average velocity: 95/31 = 3.1 sprints, so 3-4 sprints is realistic

insights: This team shows healthy velocity stability with minor variation
The slight dip in sprint 3 and 6 suggests complexity impacts but good recovery
Consistent team size and sprint length contribute to predictable velocity

scenarios.title: Growing Team - Mobile App Startup
scenarios.description: A startup team that has been scaling rapidly with changing requirements
scenarios.context: This mobile app team started with 3 developers and has grown to 7. They're dealing with evolving product requirements and technical scaling challenges.

questions.question: Why shouldn't you use the overall average velocity for planning?
questions.explanation: The team doubled in size, making early velocity data irrelevant for current planning

questions.question: Which sprints should you use to calculate current team velocity?
questions.explanation: Sprints 7-10 represent the current team size of 7 developers, making them most relevant

questions.question: What's the most appropriate velocity range for the next sprint?
questions.explanation: Based on sprints 7-10 with current team size: range of 24-35 points, so 28-35 is appropriate

insights: Team growth significantly impacts velocity - use recent data only
New team members initially decrease velocity before increasing it
Velocity stabilizes as team coordination improves

stable.planningApproach: Use recent average with small buffer

trending_up.planningApproach: Use recent higher values but be conservative

trending_down.planningApproach: Investigate root causes, use lower recent values

volatile.planningApproach: Use wider range, focus on improving consistency

simple_average.description: Sum of completed points / number of sprints
simple_average.limitations: Doesn't account for trends or outliers

weighted_average.when_to_use: Teams with improving or declining trends

median.description: Middle value when sprints are ordered by velocity

range_planning.description: Use minimum and maximum from recent sprints
range_planning.limitations: May be too conservative or optimistic
